paper_title: RAVine: Reality-Aligned Evaluation for Agentic Search

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Agentic search, as a more autonomous and adaptive paradigm of retrieval augmentation, is driving the evolution of intelligent search systems. However, existing evaluation frameworks fail to align well with the goals of agentic search. First, the complex queries commonly used in current benchmarks often deviate from realistic user search scenarios. Second, prior approaches tend to introduce noise when extracting ground truth for end-to-end evaluations, leading to distorted assessments at a fine-grained level. Third, most current frameworks focus solely on the quality of final answers, neglecting the evaluation of the iterative process inherent to agentic search. To address these limitations, we propose RAVine -- a Reality-Aligned eValuation framework for agentic LLMs with search. RAVine targets multi-point queries and long-form answers that better reflect user intents, and introduces an attributable ground truth construction strategy to enhance the accuracy of fine-grained evaluation. Moreover, RAVine examines model's interaction with search tools throughout the iterative process, and accounts for factors of efficiency. We benchmark a series of models using RAVine and derive several insights, which we hope will contribute to advancing the development of agentic search systems. The code and datasets are available at https://github.com/SwordFaith/RAVine.

sections.title:
1 Introduction
The emergence of the Retrieval-Augmented Generation [RAG; 10,
17] has addressed factuality issues in Large Language Models [LLMs;
3, 42] and fundamentally transformed the way people access in-
formation. To enable more intelligent RAG systems, the retrieval-
augmentation paradigm is undergoing a shift: from static and pas-
sive search [2, 30, 39] to agentic search [18, 31], and agent-driven
workflow systems like Deep Research [12, 23].
sections.content: As model-level capability, agentic search aims to enable adaptive and autonomous retrieval. However, existing evaluation frameworks for LLMs with agentic search are misaligned with this target in several key aspects: Misalignment between "deep search" and user needs. Some existing benchmarks encourage LLMs with agentic search to uncover answers hidden behind highly complex queries [33], where Equal contribution. While this setup partially reflects the models ability to perform deep agentic search, it diverges from typical real-world user cases, where queries are often under-specified and lack explicit constraints. In practice, as illustrated in Figure 1, users often expect not only depth but also breadthseeking to gather and integrate multiple points of information, ultimately leading to long-form, comprehensive answer. Misalignment between noisy nugget collection and precise end-to-end evaluation. Tasks that require integrating multipoints information and generating long-form outputs demand finegrained, claim-level evaluations, which frequently include task completeness and faithfulness. Some recent works propose using LLM-as-a-Judge to dynamically generate evaluation rules instead of relying on predefined ground truth [36], which can introduce instability. In grounded evaluations, nuggets1 are often treated as evidence of task completeness [25, 26]. However, present approaches fall short in terms of nugget collection effectiveness and application in fine-grained evaluation. Coelho et al. [5], Qi et al. [27] directly instruct LLM to extract nuggets from long web documents, overlooking the limitations of model capabilities and often resulting in incomplete or inaccurate nuggets. Pradeep et al. [25] alleviate collection difficulty through segment-level batched iteration, but it may result in nugget loss due to coverage issues during iteration and truncation of the maximum number of nuggets. Additionally, these methods assess task completeness and faithfulness independently, since the nuggets are not traceable back to web pages, which can lead to inconsistency and also increased evaluation cost. Misalignment between end-to-end evaluation and processoriented architecture. While end-to-end evaluation directly reflects overall performance, agentic LLMs with search are inherently process-oriented models: they autonomously iterate, invoke search tools, and read web pages during task execution. However, existing evaluation frameworks focus exclusively on quality assessment of the final report [5, 25], overlooking the intermediate behaviors and efficiency of the process, which can also provide important signals for model differentiation and capability diagnosis. Moreover, unlike classic RAG frameworks with fixed pipelines, the flexible and dynamic iterative processes of agentic LLMs also introduce challenges in runtime efficiency and expenses, particularly for tool invocations and model inference. To address the misalignments in existing evaluation methods, we propose RAVinea Reality-Aligned eValuation framework for agentic LLMs with search. RAVine is comprehensive system, encompassing the web environment, benchmark datasets, and novel evaluation method, serving as full-process, reproducible, and goal-aligned evaluation sandbox. 1Nuggets refer to gold information units extracted from gold documents associated with query; it serves as the claim-level ground truth for evaluation. Conference acronym XX, June 0305, 2018, Woodstock, NY Yilong Xu, Xiang Long, Zhi Zheng, and Jinhua Gao Figure 1: Overview of the three primary misalignments addressed by our work. From left to right: (1) The divergence between narrow benchmark queries and broad, real-world user needs. (2) The challenge of collecting reliable and traceable information nuggets for fine-grained evaluation. (3) The tendency of existing frameworks to perform end-to-end evaluation while overlooking the agents intermediate process. Specifically, we use the TREC 2024 RAG Track [24] queries as our test split, derived from Bing logs and reflecting realistic user behavior in web search scenarios. We employ MS MARCO V2.1 [1, 24], large-scale dataset of Bing web pages, as our corpus to simulate real-world web conditions and enable fine-grained end-to-end and intermediate evaluation. In our proposed evaluation method, we introduce nugget-centered evaluation approach to assess report quality, characterized by attributability and flexibility. It enables consistent assessment of task completeness and faithfulness, which avoids noise and reduces evaluation costs. Furthermore, nuggets are collected via dynamic clustering, which allows the number of nuggets to adapt to each query, supporting more realistic evaluation and query-sensitive complexity. Last but not least, our approach includes process-oriented metrics for evaluating the performance of agentic LLMs intermediate behavior and usage of search tools. We also add efficiency indicators like latency and cost to provide more comprehensive assessment of model viability. Based on RAVine, we evaluate the performance of series of models. Our analysis reveals three key findings: (1) current models exhibit limitations in task completeness, faithfulness, and search performance; (2) strong performance during the search process does not necessarily lead to high-quality final answers; and (3) models exhibit tendency to rely on internal knowledge to generate the final report, which is an unattributable and undesirable behavior that has been overlooked in previous evaluation. In summary, our core contributions are as follows: We propose RAVine, novel evaluation framework for agentic search, designed to address the misalignment issues in existing evaluation methodologies. We introduce comprehensive evaluation system that encompasses multiple dimensions, including fine-grained endto-end assessment, intermediate process evaluation, and efficiency analysis. We conduct extensive experiments across range of LLMs, yielding valuable insights that offer meaningful directions for future research on agentic search.

2.1 Static Web Environment
Ensuring temporally consistent, fine-grained evaluation for long-
form report generation in dynamic environments is inherently
challenging, as real-world user scenarios often lack strong con-
straints, making it difficult to establish stable ground truths over
time. To address this issue, we propose using a static web corpus
that approximates a real-world internet environment. Specifically,
we adopt MS MARCO V2.1 [24], a deduplicated version of the origi-
nal MS MARCO V2 corpus [1]. This corpus contains 10,960,555 web
documents spanning diverse domains, making it well-suited for use
as a simulated environment. Moreover, it includes rich metadata
such as URLs, titles, and headings, which facilitates the construction
of standardized search tools.
sections.content: We build indexes over the MS MARCO V2.1 corpus to support the implementation of our search tools. To select an indexing strategy best suited to this corpus, we first constructed development set from TREC Deep Learning Track [6], including DL21, DL22, and DL23 datasets, which feature range of multihop, multi-source queries. These datasets include relevance annotations with respect to the MS MARCO V2 corpus, which we map to the corresponding webs in MS MARCO V2.1. We then evaluate series of embedding models on this development set. Based on their retrieval performance and computational efficiency, we select gte-modernbert-base [40], which offers the best trade-off between accuracy and speed. In addition, we also construct traditional BM25 index [29] to facilitate robustness testing. 3.1 Attributable Nuggets Collection
Previous approaches for evaluating task completeness have often
relied on document-level nugget extraction. However, a document
is a relatively coarse-grained unit that is often lengthy, making it
challenging for LLM-Judge to handle effectively. In contrast, a seg-
ment is a relatively fine-grained unit that is more aligned with claim
statements. Pradeep et al. [25] adopt a segment-level nuggets min-
ing approach. Nevertheless, their iterative strategy, which updates
a fixed-size nugget list, might become unstable, causing previously
extracted important nuggets to be overwritten, resulting in infor-
mation loss. Additionally, size restriction of nugget lists can also
lead to inaccurate evaluations, as many queries yield more nuggets
than the predefined limit. For faithfulness evaluation, we expect
that the contents of the report matching the nuggets should cite
the original web pages from which those nuggets were extracted.
However, existing nugget extraction methods are non-attributable,
and must evaluate task completeness and faithfulness separately,
which may result in inconsistency and distortion in evaluation.
sections.content: To address these issues, we propose an attributable and more flexible nugget collection method, as illustrated in Figure 3. To mitigate context length issues that may lead to LLM-Judge performance degradation, we adopt the segment-level extraction strategy, focusing on short segments rather than longer documents that often contain more noise. Both our development and test sets include segment-level qrels, either directly provided or derived via mapping. Next, when constructing batches, we group segments originating from the same document and input them into the LLM-Judge for nugget extraction. Based on our investigation, the number of relevant segments per document is typically limited, which helps keep the context length within manageable bounds. Moreover, since MS Figure 2: The architecture of the agentic LLM with search. The core model (M) iteratively interacts with web Corpus by invoking two primary tools: search, which retrieves list of web pages for given query, and fetch, which retrieves the content for given URL. This cyclical process continues until the agent has gathered sufficient information to produce the final answer.

been manually curated by annotators, often requiring multi-faceted

MARCO V2.1 employs sliding window strategy for segmentation which results in overlapping content between adjacent segments, grouping segments from the same document into batch enables the LLM to perform effective deduplication. Most importantly, because each batch corresponds to specific web page, the nuggets generated from it can be reliably attributed to their source, providing robust foundation for attributable nuggetization. Next, we project all initially extracted nuggets into semantic space using an embedding model and perform dynamic clustering. Specifically, we apply HDBSCAN [22], density-based clustering algorithm, to group semantically similar nuggets into clusters and identify outliersi.e., nuggets that are relatively dissimilar to others. For each cluster, we prompt the LLM to merge similar nuggets within the cluster and attribute the merged nugget to all original nuggets in that cluster. This design allows single nugget to be associated with multiple source webs, reflecting the information redundancy and sharing commonly observed in real-world web environments. For each query, we treat the merged nuggets from all clusters, along with the identified outliers, as the final nugget list. This approach offers two key benefits: (1) semantic merging helps dynamically control the total number of nuggets and reduces the difficulty of LLM-based merging, and (2) filtering out outliers further reduces the computational overhead for LLM-based merging. At the dataset level, we analyze the distribution of nugget counts across different queries in the test set. Instead of applying fixed heuristic cutoff to all queries, we selectively truncate only those with an excessively large number of nuggets in order to mitigate evaluation costs. This strategy is more flexible and generalizable, allowing the evaluation data to retain diverse range of information densities. Further details are provided in Appendix A.2. Following Pradeep et al. [25], we instruct the LLM-Judge to perform batched nugget scoring to support task completeness evaluation. Each nugget is labeled as either vital, indicating that it is highly important and must be included in the report, or okay, meaning it contains good-to-have information for the query but is not essential.

3.2 Block-level Assignment
With the availability of attributable nuggets, we can perform a joint
evaluation of task completeness and faithfulness to mitigate incon-
sistencies and distortions. The first step is to select an appropriate
granularity for segmenting the long-form report, which serves as
the basic evaluation unit. Prior evaluation methods typically adopt
sentence-level granularity [9, 21], and some of them penalize sen-
tences without citations [5, 25]. However, not all sentences in a
report constitute factual statements, as some may reflect common
sense or general knowledge that does not require citation. Moreover,
a complete factual statement may span multiple sentences. Existing
approaches often rely on LLMs to directly extract factual statements
[25, 27], but this can introduce noise and reduce reliability.

sections.title:
5.1 Experimental Setup
In our proposed RAVine framework, we build both dense and lex-
ical indexes for the web environment on which the search and
fetch tools rely. Specifically, we use the gte-modernbert-base
[40] model to build the dense index, implemented with FAISS [7],
and adopt BM25 [29] for the lexical index, implemented using Py-
serini [20]. In the nugget-centered report quality evaluation, we use
the gemini-2.5-flash (without thinking) [11] as the LLM in both
nugget extraction and report scoring. All the prompt templates in
the process can be found in Appendix A.3.
sections.content: We select several state-of-the-art agentic LLMs with tool-use capabilities for evaluation, including Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct [28], Qwen2.5-32B-Instruct [28], Qwen3-8B [37], Qwen3-32B [37], Qwen330B-A3B [37] and LLaMA-3.1-8B-Instruct [13]. For models that support thinking switch, such as the Qwen3 series, we evaluate their performance under both thinking and non-thinking modes. We divide the evaluation of all models into two groups based on the maximum context length: 32k and 128k. For each group, we conduct separate evaluations using the two different indexes. All experiments are conducted on machine with 8 H100 GPUs.

An effective search behavior should achieve both high recall and high marginal gain, demonstrating both breadth and depth in information seeking. "Thinking" enhances agentic search. Under the thinking mode, models generally achieve higher task completion rates and task completeness scores, as the thinking mode enables the model to develop deeper understanding of the user query and the required information, leading to more deliberate and effective tool use. Although thinking mode introduces additional latency and costs in token generation, the mode without thinking often results in more aggressive and inefficient tool calls, such as Qwen3-8B without thinking, which significantly increases the overall cost. Attribution is impacted by reliance on internal knowledge. When performing factual tasks, LLMs may rely not only on retrieved external knowledge but also on their internal knowledge to generate responses. To investigate this behavior, we calculate the proportion of task completeness scores that relies on internal knowledge, and denote this metric as Compin. Specifically, if model fails to retrieve any web pages that hit the qrels during the iterative process, we consider the final score of this run to be based on internal knowledge, and this score contributes to Compin. As shown in Figure 5, significant portion of task performance across models can be traceable to internal knowledge. For some models, more than half of the nuggets are hit by internal knowledge. While such internal knowledge may be accurate for some non-long-tail facts, it cannot be attributable through citations. Such behavior can impair the faithfulness and verifiability, which is undesirable in the context of search-augmented systems and has been overlooked by previous evaluation frameworks. The illusion of progress: Intermediate performance does not always translate to final outcomes. As shown in Figure 4, we observe no significant positive correlation between the final task completeness scores and search precision scores. To investigate this phenomenon, we employ the Compin metric and categorize each run into those relying on internal knowledge versus those relying on retrieved knowledge. Linear regression analysis reveals that runs depending on retrieved knowledge exhibit more pronounced positive correlation between task completeness and search precision. This suggests that excessive reliance on internal knowledge is one of the factors contributing to the discrepancy between intermediate and final performance. Moreover, if the model is capable of incorporating effective search performance into the final report, our framework can encourage this good behavior through higher scores.

sections.title: 6 Related Work
sections.content: Retrieval-Augmented Generation. Retrieval-Augmented Generation [RAG; 10, 17] enhances Large Language Models [LLMs; 42] by incorporating external knowledge retrieval, thereby mitigating hallucinations that arise when relying solely on internal parameters [41]. Beyond producing accurate and up-to-date answers, RAG also improves the faithfulness and verifiability of generated content by attributing information to source documents via citations [9, 21, 34]. However, traditional RAG paradigms [30, 35, 39] rely on fixed retrieval pipelines that are overly dependent on the initial query and lack interaction with the retrieved content, resulting in suboptimal performance. Agentic Search and Deep Research. To enable more autonomous and adaptive RAG paradigm, agentic search has emerged as novel approach to augment generation [18, 31]. In contrast to traditional RAG methods that heavily rely on retrieval performance, agentic RAG leverages LLMs to actively guide the search process and reflect on subsequent actions [15, 19]. To better support customized information needs, Deep Research systems adopt product-level design that implements carefully structured agent workflow for more comprehensive and targeted search [12, 23, 43]. As core modellevel capability, agentic search plays crucial role in determining both the performance of downstream RAG tasks and the upper bound of search agent capabilities. However, existing evaluation frameworks are often misaligned with the goals of agentic search and real-world user search tasks. Evaluation. Traditional RAG datasets primarily focus on multihop QA tasks involving the retrieval of factual entities [4, 14, 32, 38]. To support more challenging search evaluations, Wei et al. [33] employ highly complex queries to assess models deep retrieval capabilities. However, these benchmarks often diverge from real-world user search scenarios, where queries tend to be less constrained and users typically expect long-form, comprehensive answers [8, 16]. Moreover, current evaluation frameworks may introduce noise when extracting fine-grained ground truth unitsi.e., nuggets, due to limitations in LLM capabilities and information loss, which in turn leads to distorted evaluation outcomes [5, 25]. In addition, many existing frameworks focus solely on end-to-end performance, overlooking critical aspects of agentic search such as intermediate thinking and tool invocation, which are essential to understanding and improving model behavior. To address the limitations of prior related work, we propose RAVine, Reality-Aligned eValuation framework for agentic LLMs with search capabilities.

We believe this design aims to control evaluation cost, but at the expense of evaluation accuracy. To address the evaluation distortion caused by such nugget truncation, we conduct quantitative analysis of the distribution of all nuggets extracted by the LLMs, as shown in Figure 6. The transformation from segments to nuggets and then to vital nuggets represents progressive filtering process that reduces the amount of information. According to the distribution, 95% of the queries contain no more than 108.84 nuggetsfar exceeding the preset limit of 30 in Pradeep et al. [25]. To strike balance between preserving the majority of informational content and maintaining evaluation efficiency, we set the nugget cap at the 95th percentile (P95) of the vital nuggets distribution, which corresponds to count of 56.15. We round this to 60 as the final nugget limit. This threshold prevents both excessive evaluation cost from queries with disproportionately many nuggets (which are arguably anomalous) and information loss due to arbitrary truncation. Compared to fixed limit, this percentile-based, data-driven truncation strategy offers more principled and adaptive approach. In the final report quality evaluation, we assign the degree of support for each nugget by calling state-of-the-art proprietary LLM via its API. Specifically, we employed the then-current version Gemini-2.5-Flash in our implementation, which is gemini-2. 5-flash-preview-05-20. As the latest officially released gemini-2. 5-flash model is identical to the preview-05-20 version, our usage can be regarded as equivalent to the official version. We define Task Completion Rate as the proportion of successful runs out of all executed runs. Citation Recall & Precision. Our citation evaluation is performed at the block level. For each block, we identify the nuggets it hits and extract their associated source web pages to construct the set of gold citations. Since we merge nuggets during the nugget collection stage, single nugget may correspond to multiple source web pages. To prevent any nugget from having an excessive number of source web pages (e.g., more than three), which could lead the model to cite an unreasonable number of pages for single claim (both impractical and of limited utility), we intersect the gold citations with the set of web pages retrieved by the model during its iterative search in the current run. This constraint aligns with the more realistic assumption that model should only cite from documents it has discovered. In addition, to prevent nuggets from having an excessive number of gold citations, we impose hard upper limit in the calculation of citation recall: the number of gold citations per nugget is capped at maximum of three. This approach helps prevent models from generating an excessive number of citations to game the reward from the metric, and also mitigates the risk of information overload. Previous approaches typically treat all gold citations equally. However, our analysis suggests that different gold citations should be assigned different priorities. For instance, within single block where multiple nuggets are matched, some web pages may support only one nugget, while others serve as the source for multiple Conference acronym XX, June 0305, 2018, Woodstock, NY Yilong Xu, Xiang Long, Zhi Zheng, and Jinhua Gao nuggets simultaneously. In such cases, web pages supporting multiple nuggets should be prioritized for citation. Accordingly, we incorporate this intuition into our implementation of citation recall by introducing weighted gold citations, where each citation is assigned weight proportional to the number of nuggets it supports. Furthermore, when the number of gold citations exceeds the predefined upper limit, we normalize the total weight by considering only the top three gold citations with the highest weights. model can achieve full recall only if it cites these top three sources. This strategy ensures that higher-quality citation behavior is rewarded more, while discouraging the model from producing large number of low-quality citations. Search Recall. The search recall metric evaluates the models ability to retrieve multi-point useful information throughout the entire iterative process. It is computed based on the source web pages associated with the nuggets for each query. To prevent the metric from being diluted in cases where nugget has large number of relevant web pages, we also impose the cap of three relevant web pages per nugget during evaluation. For example, if nugget has more than three relevant sources and the model retrieves any three of them, the search recall for that nugget is considered to be 1. The final search recall for run is calculated as the average search recall across all nuggets. This approach also effectively discourages the model from repeatedly retrieving documents for the same information point in one run to boost its evaluation score. Search Gain. For the calculation of search gain, we similarly address the issue of nuggets being associated with large number of relevant web pages. Specifically, we limit the number of relevant pages per nugget to maximum of three. As result, the total set of information gain is further deduplicated and reduced in size.
